briefings.headline: Andreessen Horowitz’s Midha Forms New Venture
briefings.dek: Midha previously ran Andreessen’s effort to supply startups with access to Nvidia graphics processing units.
briefings.body:
Andreessen Horowitz general partner Anjney Midha is launching AMP, a new venture to provide “compute and capital to frontier AI teams.” Midha, The Information reported. Midha, who previously helped Andreessen startups access Nvidia GPUs, will remain a part-time venture partner, retaining board seats on companies like Mistral and Black Forest Labs.

Midha’s new venture highlights the increasing demand for compute power among AI startups. At Andreessen, he led Oxygen, a group that managed thousands of Nvidia chips for rent to startups, which helped the firm secure competitive investments.

Andreessen is one of the few VC firms that rent or buy GPUs to then rent to their backed startups, a practice some firms avoid due to management overhead and hardware depreciation concerns. The firm’s program began with plans for over 20,000 chips and has since expanded to multiple private clusters.

related_items.title: Andreessen Horowitz General Partner Midha to Establish Compute Firm

briefings.headline: OpenAI Working on a Music Generating Tool
briefings.dek: The AI startup has enlisted the help of Juilliard School to create training data for the effort.
briefings.body:
OpenAI is developing artificial intelligence to allow people to generate music using text and audio prompts, The Information reported.

The startup is collaborating with Juilliard School students to annotate music scores, which can be used as training data for the music generating tool. The company is discussing AI that can add guitar to vocal tracks or create music for videos, potentially aiding advertising agencies in generating jingles and brainstorming lyrics. This move positions OpenAI to compete with Google, which launched its music-making model, Lyria, in May.

OpenAI could face potential copyright lawsuits over the tool from music labels like Universal Music Group and Sony, which have sued other AI music generators. The startup has already taken some steps to stay out of hot water with the music industry, such as by summarizing copyrighted lyrics.

related_items.title: OpenAI Moves to Generate AI Music in Potential Rivalry With Startup Suno

briefings.headline: SoftBank Board Approves Remainder of OpenAI Investment
briefings.dek: The AI startup still needs to complete its conversion to a public benefit corporation to get SoftBank’s $22.5 billion investment.
briefings.body:
SoftBank is set to complete its $30 billion investment in OpenAI, after its board approved a $22.5 billion second installment on the deal, The Information reported. The remainder of its investment is contingent on OpenAI’s corporate restructuring, which would pave the way for a public offering and transform it into a public benefit corporation.

The SoftBank investment is part of a larger $41 billion financing round, which valued OpenAI at $260 billion. The new funds are critical for OpenAI’s escalating compute expenses, projected at $16 billion this year and $40 billion next year, with an additional $100 billion budgeted through 2030 for research breakthroughs.

An OpenAI IPO is still distant due to its current non-profit structure, established in 2015. Early investors and employees hold rights to future profits rather than equity.

related_items.title: SoftBank Greenlights Remaining $22.5 Billion of OpenAI Investment

briefings.headline: Nvidia Rival SambaNova Considers a Sale
briefings.dek: The AI chip maker struggled recently to complete a fundraising round.
briefings.body:
Artificial intelligence chip startup SambaNova Systems is exploring a sale after it was unable to complete a fundraising round, The Information reported.

The Palo Alto, Calif., company, last valued at $5 billion in 2021, has faced sales growth challenges against competitors like Nvidia. As a result, the startup hired an investment bank to represent in a potential sale. The company could decide not to move forward with the plan though.

Acquisitions of smaller chip startups are increasing this year, with Meta acquiring Rivos and Advanced Micro Devices hiring staff from Untether AI. SambaNova, founded in 2017, designs custom AI chips to rival Nvidia’s GPUs and has raised over $1.1 billion in funding. CEO Rodrigo Liang claims their technology outperforms Nvidia GPUs at a tenth of the power. A spokesperson for SambaNova stated the company evaluates strategic opportunities but did not comment on sale talks.

related_items.title: AI Chip Startup SambaNova Explores Sale After Stalled Fundraising

briefings.headline: Google Investigates Security Breach Related to Play Store
briefings.dek: The incident involved a contractor in the Philippines, who was later fired.
briefings.body:
Google is investigating a security breach involving a contractor who took nearly 2,000 screenshots and sensitive internal files related to the Google Play store, The Information reported.

The contractor, working in the Philippines for Accenture, sent the images to an unidentified outsider via WhatsApp and Telegram between July and September. The copied material included software code and information on developer accounts and fraud review processes, which could potentially help someone upload malicious apps by understanding how the app store suspends them. Google confirmed the information could inform developers about trust and safety guidelines but stated it’s not a “master key” to bypass security.

Google launched its investigation in September, leading to the contractor’s admission of being paid for sending the files and subsequent termination. The company stated there’s no indication of compromised Google or user security.

related_items.title: Google Investigates Weekslong Security Breach Involving Contractor

briefings.headline: Trump, Xi Jinping Could ‘Consummate’ TikTok Deal This Week, Treasury Secretary Says
briefings.dek: The two leaders are set to meet Thursday in South Korea.
briefings.body:
Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said Sunday that President Donald Trump and China’s leader, Xi Jinping, could this week “consummate” a long-anticipated deal to keep TikTok operating in the U.S., as the leaders prepare to meet Thursday in South Korea.

President Trump recently signed an executive order approving the proposed deal, which involves selling some of TikTok’s U.S. business to a new joint-venture company for $14 billion. Speaking on CBS News’ Face the Nation Sunday, Bessent said a final deal had been reached and “as of today, all the details are ironed out, and that will be for the two leaders to consummate that transaction on Thursday in Korea.”

But details of the deal itself remain scarce. It’s unclear who the final line up of investors will include, for example, and what parts of TikTok’s U.S. business will be overseen by the new venture.

briefings.headline: U.S. Regulator Asks Tesla for Info About New ‘Mad Max’ Driving Mode
briefings.dek: Videos posted by drivers on social media purport to show the software driving well above speed limits, such as going 65 miles per hour in a 45 mile per hour zone.
briefings.body:
The U.S. National Highway Safety Administration says it has contacted Tesla to gather more information about a new setting on its driver assistance software that makes its vehicles move faster and more aggressively.

Tesla added the setting, called “Mad Max,” in an update for users of its “Full Self-Driving” software earlier this month. In a note to users accompanying the update, Tesla said the setting “comes with higher speeds and more frequent lane changes” than other settings. Videos posted by drivers on social media purport to show the software driving well above speed limits, such as going 65 miles per hour in a 45 mile per hour zone. A NHTSA spokesperson said in a statement on Friday that the agency had contacted Tesla and noted that “the human behind the wheel is fully responsible for driving the vehicle and complying with all traffic safety laws.”

The news comes after the NHTSA opened an investigation into Tesla’s FSD software earlier in October prior to the release of the “Mad Max” update. The agency, which is part of the U.S. Department of Transportation, said at the time that it had identified 58 reports of vehicles using the software running red lights and violating other traffic laws. The Washington Post first reported the NHTSA’s most recent request for information. Tesla did not respond to a request for comment.

briefings.headline: JPMorgan Poaches BofA’s Veteran Tech Banker Kevin Brunner
briefings.dek: It's the latest JPMorgan's hire from rivals to boost its technology banking practice.
briefings.body:
JPMorgan hired veteran technology banker Kevin Brunner from Bank of America as a global chair of investment banking and mergers and acquisitions, according to a memo viewed by The Information.

Brunner spent all his career at Bank of America and was most recently chair of global M&A. He advised on large deals such as Google’s $32 billion acquisition of cybersecurity startup Wiz and Broadcom on its $69 billion acquisition of VMware.

JPMorgan has been hiring from rivals to boost its technology banking practice. In May, it hired four senior bankers from Goldman Sachs, Bank of America and Lazard.

A spokesperson for JPMorgan confirmed the content of the memo. A spokesperson for Bank of America declined to comment.

briefings.headline: Chinese Humanoid Startup AgiBot Unveils Robot Content Platform
briefings.dek: The startup says the new platform automatically converts uploaded videos of human movements into robots’ actions.
briefings.body:
Chinese humanoid robot maker AgiBot on Friday unveiled a “robot content creation platform” that allows users to upload videos of human movements so a humanoid can accurately mimic them.

The Shanghai-based startup said that the platform, LinkCraft, will allow end-users with no expertise in programming or robots to casually participate in the process of developing specific actions for humanoids, a process that traditionally requires a lot of resources like specialized equipment, algorithmic modeling and extensive fine-tuning.

LinkCraft automatically converts human movements into humanoid actions using technologies such as AI motion capture and imitation learning, a technique that makes robots learn to perform tasks by mimicking human demonstrations, the company said.

AgiBot was founded in 2023 by Zhihui Peng, a former member of Huawei Technologies’ “Genius Youth” program. It is one of a growing number of Chinese startups that are racing to develop more capable humanoids by taking advantage of the country’s vast hardware supply chain and deep talent pool in AI and advanced robotics. The startup’s backers include tech giant Tencent Holdings and Chinese venture capital firm HongShan, according to PitchBook.

briefings.headline: Commerce Dept. Denies Talks for Quantum Investments
briefings.dek: Quantum stocks jumped earlier in the day on a report of the talks.
briefings.body:
The U.S. Commerce Depart. denied that it is “currently negotiating equity stakes with quantum computing companies,” according to CNBC, countering a news report earlier in the day that sent shares of several stocks soaring.

Earlier Thursday, The Wall Street Journal reported that the department is considering equity investments worth at least $10 million in several quantum computing companies.

IonQ, Rigetti Computing, D-Wave Quantum, Quantum Computing and startup Atom Computing are discussing the arrangement, according to the report. Share prices of each of the public companies rose at least 7% during the day.

There is precedent for the Trump administration to make investments in U.S. companies it considers strategic assets. In August, the U.S. government agreed to buy 9.9% of Intel for $8.9 billion. In July, the government said it would invest $400 million in MP Materials, which operates a rare earth mine.

On Wednesday, Google published new research on quantum computing, showing that the frontier technology can be used to understand the structures of molecules such as proteins or materials such as phone batteries.

briefings.headline: Intel Expects to Benefit as More Companies Adopt AI Apps
briefings.dek: Intel's turnaround appears to be continuing after the chipmaker beat its quarterly sales forecast, while its senior leaders struck a positive tone on AI.
briefings.body:
On Intel’s third-quarter earnings call, CEO Lip-Bu Tan and CFO David Zinsner said the chipmaker is expecting a boost as more companies shift their spending from training AI models to inference, the process of using trained models to power AI applications.

That’s because Intel expects that many companies will use server CPU chips for inference as opposed to graphics processing units from Nvidia and AMD.

“It is increasingly clear that CPUs play a critical role today and will going forward within the AI data center as AI usage expands, and especially as inference workloads outpace that of training,” Zinsner said on the call.

There were other signs that Intel’s turnaround is underway: Revenue jumped 6% to $13.7 billion, or $100 million more than the high end of its forecast. Net income, excluding items, was $4.1 billion, breaking a string of six consecutive quarterly losses.

The optimistic tone was a contrast to Intel’s earnings calls over the past few years, which have been mostly downbeat. Shares rose 3% after the earnings report. While Intel still has a long way to go, it’s in a much better spot than it was a year ago.

briefings.headline: Anthropic Says It Will Use Up to 1 Million Google TPU Chips
briefings.dek: Google's AI chip is challenging Nvidia's GPUs.
briefings.body:
Anthropic on Thursday said it plans to use up to 1 million Google Tensor processing units to power its artificial intelligence, implying the startup would spend tens of billions of dollars renting TPU servers. The announcement is a show of confidence in Google’s chip as an alternative to Nvidia’s graphics processing unit, which dominates the AI server market.

Anthropic didn’t provide more details except to say that next year, the TPUs in its deal with Google will power a gigawatt of data center capacity. Developing a 1 GW data center costs tens of billions of dollars.

It isn’t clear whether the TPUs for Anthropic would be run by Google Cloud or at data centers operated by other cloud providers. Recently, Google struck a deal to put a large number of TPUs in a New York data center run by cloud provider Fluidstack, The Information reported, but it wasn’t clear who would use the TPUs.

TPUs historically only ran inside Google Cloud, and the most advanced version of the chip was restricted to Google’s in-house AI teams. Google offers servers powered by the chip as an alternative to Nvidia’s GPUs, though Google Cloud is also one of the biggest buyers of GPUs, as many cloud customers prefer using those chips. Anthropic says it uses a mix of TPUs, GPUs, and Amazon’s Trainium AI chips. OpenAI at one point was testing TPUs but later said it didn’t have plans to use them at scale.

Both Google and Amazon own significant stakes in Anthropic and have invested billions of dollars in the company. Anthropic spends billions of dollars a year renting servers from Google and Amazon’s cloud units.

briefings.headline: OpenAI Acquires AI Startup Software Applications Incorporated
briefings.dek: The startup builds Sky, a “natural language interface” for Mac computers
briefings.body:
OpenAI on Thursday said it bought Software Applications Inc. for an undisclosed sum. The two-year-old artificial intelligence startup develops Sky, which allows Mac users to take action on their screens and within apps using text-based prompts.

“With Sky, AI works alongside you, whether you’re writing, planning, coding, or managing your day,” OpenAI said in a blog post.

All twelve of Software Applications’ employees, many of whom were former Apple employees, will join the company. The startup previously raised $6.5 million, including from an investment fund affiliated with OpenAI CEO Sam Altman, OpenAI has said.

OpenAI has previously spent roughly $6.4 billion in stock to acquire Jony Ive’s hardware startup io, product analytics startup Statsig, and search and analytics database company Rockset. OpenAI has also hired top researchers in hardware and AI from Apple.

briefings.headline: Trump Says He Won’t Send National Guard to SF After Calls From Tech ‘Friends’
briefings.dek: Trump said he had received a call from Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff, who recently walked back his support for the plan.
briefings.body:
President Donald Trump has called off plans to send the National Guard on Saturday into San Francisco, after he said friends who live in the area urged him not to go ahead with it.

“Great people like Jensen Huang, Marc Benioff, and others have called saying that the future of San Francisco is great,” Trump said in a post on Truth Social. “They want to give it a “shot.” Therefore, we will not surge San Francisco on Saturday.”

The mention of Benioff is notable. In a recent interview with The New York Times, Benioff praised Trump and said he supported deploying National Guard troops in San Francisco. The comments sparked backlash and led prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist Ron Conway to resign from the board of Salesforce’s philanthropic arm. Benioff later apologized for the comments but not before the Times published a separate report revealing that Salesforce had been pitching Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) for government contracts.

briefings.headline: Redwood Materials Raises $350 Million for Data Center Batteries
briefings.dek: Nevada-based startup's valuation rises to $6 billion
briefings.body:
Battery materials company Redwood Materials said Thursday it had raised $350 million  to expand of its new line of business repurposing used batteries to power AI data centers. Its new valuation, of more than $6 billion, is 20% higher than its last fundraising in 2023.

The funding, led by Palo Alto, Calif-based Eclipse Ventures and Nvidia venture arm NVentures, illustrates how stationary storage batteries have emerged as a bright spot as many Western Western battery startups are strapped for cash and some have gone bankrupt. The round comes two weeks after Texas residential stationary battery maker Base Power, co-founded by entrepreneur Zach Dell, raised $1 billion.

Tesla co-founder JB Straubel founded Redwood in 2017 to recycle defective and dead lithium-ion batteries and sell the resulting metals back to customers like GM, Panasonic and Toyota to be turned again into batteries. With the electric vehicle industry taking off slowly, Redwood later broadened its business lines into making cathodes, the costliest component in a battery.

Then, in July, Redwood said that many of the batteries it gathered had plenty of energy left in them, creating an opportunity to turn them into cheap power for energy-hungry data centers. It created a new subsidiary, Redwood Energy, as we reported.

In a tweet Thursday, Gene Munster, co-founder of Deepwater Asset Management, said he expects stationary batteries eventually to be Redwood’s biggest business.

briefings.headline: Globalstar’s Stock Moves Up 8% Following Report from The Information
briefings.dek: The satellite provider’s top executive has told others he’s open to selling Globalstar for more than $10 billion.
briefings.body:
Satellite company Globalstar shares surged nearly 8% on Thursday following The Information’s report that the company has been looking to sell itself for more than $10 billion.

The company has been owned by investor James Monroe’s Thermo Companies since 2004 when he acquired the then beleaguered satellite company out of bankruptcy. After turning the company around and establishing a partnership with Apple, Monroe has been looking for a potential exit.

Apple can be a tricky partner though. Globalstar’s interest in selling itself could be one of several developments that increase the likelihood of a satellite partnership between Apple and Elon Musk’s SpaceX, The Information also reported. In Globalstar’s most recent quarterly earnings filing, it wrote about Apple: “The loss of the Customer would likely have a material adverse impact on our financial condition, results of operations and cash flows.”

related_items.title: Apple’s Satellite Ambitions Threatened by Elon Musk, Internal Resistance

briefings.headline: Exclusive: Startup Synthesia Discusses GV-Led Fundraise at $4 Billion Valuation
briefings.dek: Synthesia previously talked with Adobe and Meta about a potential sale.
briefings.body:
Synthesia, a London-based maker of artificial intelligence software that generates video avatars of people, is in talks to raise a new round of funding led by early investor GV, an investment arm of Google-owner Alphabet, at a $4 billion valuation including the investment, according to two people with knowledge of the discussions.

The startup recently passed $150 million in annual recurring revenue, up 50% from April. The fundraising discussions follow M&A talks with Adobe, which considered buying the startup for $3 billion, as well as talks about a potential sale to Meta Platforms, The Information reported Wednesday. Neither talks advanced. Synthesia last raised venture funding at the start of the year at a $2.1 billion valuation in a fundraising led by NEA.

The current fundraise hasn’t closed and terms could still change.

related_items.title: Adobe Discussed $3 Billion Acquisition of AI Video Startup Synthesia

briefings.headline: NBA Coach and Player Ensnared in Sports Betting Indictments
briefings.dek: The NBA suspended a Portland Trailblazers coach and a Miami Heat guard following the indictments.
briefings.body:
The current coach of the NBA’s Portland Trailblazers and a guard for the Miami Heat were among dozens of arrests Thursday morning as part of a sprawling nationwide probe by the FBI into illegal sports betting and gambling schemes, whereby the government alleges that current and former NBA players and coaches conspired with others to defraud major sports betting companies.

In one of two indictments, both brought by the U.S. Attorney’s Office in the Eastern District of New York, accused Chauncey Billups, the Trailblazers coach and a Hall of Fame former player, and others of participating in a Mafia-led scheme of rigging illegal poker games. A second indictment accused Terry Rozier, the Heat guard, and others of orchestrating wagers on sports betting apps with insider information with respect to NBA games, such as player injuries and in-game performance.

In a statement, the NBA said that Billups and Rozier have been placed on “immediate leave” and that the league is cooperating with authorities in the probe. “We take these allegations with the utmost seriousness, and the integrity of our game remains our top priority,” the league said.

The indictment involving Rozier says the defendants conspired to defraud betting companies, including two unnamed entities that are co-official sports betting partners of the NBA. The NBA lists DraftKings and FanDuel as its official gaming partners on its website. “This is the insider trading saga for the NBA,” said FBI director Kash Patel on Thursday.

In all, authorities said they arrested more than 30 individuals across 11 states in relation to the probe. The indictment involving Billups alleges a complex and elaborate scheme involving several prominent Italian crime families to rig poker games and defraud bettors out of tens or hundreds of thousands of dollars at a time. Three defendants—including Damon Jones, a former Cleveland Cavaliers player and coach—were charged in both indictments.

briefings.headline: Ellison’s Paramount Has Made Three Bids for WBD
briefings.dek: Earlier this week WBD said it was reviewing its "strategic alternatives," which is code for putting itself on the market.
briefings.body:
The Ellison family’s Paramount Skydance has made three offers for Warner Bros. Discovery in the past month, at steadily rising prices, the New York Times reported on Thursday. All the offers were rejected.

Paramount’s offers for WBD began at $19 a share and rose to $23.50 a share. Before Paramount’s interest in buying WBD became public in mid-September, WBD stock was trading between $12 and $13. On Thursday it was up 3% at $21.17, giving the company a market capitalization of $52 billion. Including WBD’s debt, it has an enterprise value of about $81.5 billion.

Earlier this week WBD said it was reviewing its “strategic alternatives,” which is code for putting itself on the market. The company had previously announcd it would split in two, carving its slowly-shrinking but profitable cable channels off from its streaming and film studio business. It will explore a range of options now,  now, including a sale of the entire company or of the studio and/or the cable channels.

briefings.headline: HongShan Leads Fundraising in AI Agent Genspark
briefings.dek: The funding round, which is still ongoing, elevates the startup’s valuation to the north of $1 billion.
briefings.body:
HongShan, the Chinese venture capital giant formerly known as Sequoia Capital China, is leading the funding round in artificial intelligence agent Genspark that will value the startup at more than $1 billion, according to two people with knowledge of the deal.

Genspark has secured commitments from HongShan, led by prominent venture capitalist Neil Shen, as it continues to talk to other investors, according to the people. Forbes on Wednesday reported that Genspark is in talks to raise over $200 million in the round from investors including LG Technology Ventures and Japan’s SBI Investment. HongShan’s participation hasn’t previously been reported.

AI agents become one of the most prominent tech trends of 2025. Genspark was valued at around $500 million in its last funding round earlier this year. The startup has more than 40 employees, mainly in the U.S. and Singapore, and opened an office in Japan this month. HongShan is also an investor in Manus, which competes with Genspark.

Founded by former Baidu executives Eric Jing and Kay Zhu, Genspark launched a general-purpose AI agent called Super Agent in April and has since added many new functions to it. In September, the startup, which generates revenue from premium subscriptions, said it had surpassed $50 million in annualized run rate, just five months after the launch of Super Agent.

related_items.title: Startup Behind Manus AI Agent Navigates U.S.-China Tensions After Benchmark Deal
